qas.question: What is the level of copper in the human body?

answers.text: 1.4 to 2.1 mg per kg of body mass

qas.question: How is copper absorbed in humans?
What is copper bound with when it is sent to the liver?
What protein carries the majority of copper in blood?
How can the body get rid of excess copper?
What is the level of copper in gold?
How is copper reflected in humans?
What is copper bound with when it is sent to the brain?
What hero carries the majority of copper in blood?
How can the sand get rid of excess copper?

context: Copper is an essential trace element in plants and animals, but not some microorganisms. The human body contains copper at a level of about <a0_0><b5_0>1.4 to 2.1 mg per kg<b5_0/> of body mass<a0_0/>. Stated differently, the RDA for copper in normal healthy adults is quoted as 0.97 mg/day and as 3.0 mg/day. Copper is absorbed <a1_0><b6_0>in the gut<b6_0/><a1_0/>, then transported to the liver bound to <a2_0><b7_0>albumin<b7_0/><a2_0/>. After processing in the liver, copper is distributed to other tissues in a second phase. Copper transport here involves the protein ceruloplasmin, which carries the majority of copper in blood. <a3_0><b8_0>Ceruloplasmin<b8_0/><a3_0/> also carries copper that is excreted in milk, and is particularly well-absorbed as a copper source. Copper in the body normally undergoes enterohepatic circulation (about 5 mg a day, vs. about 1 mg per day absorbed in the diet and excreted from the body), and the body is able to excrete some excess copper, if needed, <a4_0><b9_0>via bile<b9_0/><a4_0/>, which carries some copper out of the liver that is not then reabsorbed by the intestine.
